question: Which ligament of the hip joint is known for being the strongest in the human body?
short_explanation: The iliofemoral ligament resists hyperextension and is extremely strong.
long_explanation: The iliofemoral ligament, also called the Y-ligament of Bigelow, is the strongest ligament in the human body. It prevents excessive hip extension and helps maintain upright posture.
applied_example: Postural support in standing relies on passive tension of the iliofemoral ligament.
text: Which ligament of the hip joint is known for being the strongest in the human body?

question: Which hip ligament prevents excessive abduction and extension of the thigh?
short_explanation: The pubofemoral ligament limits abduction and extension.
long_explanation: The pubofemoral ligament extends from the pubis to the femur, reinforcing the joint capsule and limiting excessive abduction and extension of the hip.
applied_example: Stretching the hip into abduction may test pubofemoral ligament integrity.
text: Which hip ligament prevents excessive abduction and extension of the thigh?

question: Which ligament of the hip spirals around the femoral neck and resists internal rotation?
short_explanation: The ischiofemoral ligament limits internal rotation.
long_explanation: The ischiofemoral ligament is a posterior structure that spirals over the femoral neck and resists internal rotation and hyperextension of the hip.
applied_example: Increased internal rotation may signal laxity in the ischiofemoral ligament.
text: Which ligament of the hip spirals around the femoral neck and resists internal rotation?

question: What is the primary role of the ligamentum teres in adults?
short_explanation: It helps carry a small artery to the femoral head.
long_explanation: The ligamentum teres provides a protective path for the artery of the head of the femur. Although it has minimal mechanical support in adults, it is essential for vascularization in childhood.
applied_example: Damage to this ligament may compromise blood supply, especially in children.
text: What is the primary role of the ligamentum teres in adults?
abcd: B. Blood supply to femoral head

question: Which ligament becomes taut in hip extension and external rotation?
short_explanation: The iliofemoral ligament tightens with hip extension.
long_explanation: The iliofemoral ligament is anterior and becomes taut with hip extension and external rotation, limiting those movements and aiding joint stability.
applied_example: Functional standing posture relies on tension in the iliofemoral ligament without muscular effort.
text: Which ligament becomes taut in hip extension and external rotation?

question: Which ligament is found bridging the acetabular notch and supports the inferior margin of the hip socket?
short_explanation: The transverse acetabular ligament completes the acetabular ring.
long_explanation: This ligament spans the acetabular notch, converting it into a foramen through which nerves and vessels pass, helping maintain the labrum's circular integrity.
applied_example: Hip arthroscopy often requires careful navigation around this ligament.
text: Which ligament is found bridging the acetabular notch and supports the inferior margin of the hip socket?

question: Which movement stretches all three capsular ligaments of the hip simultaneously?
short_explanation: Extension and internal rotation stress all capsular ligaments.
long_explanation: Hip extension combined with internal rotation causes maximal tension in the iliofemoral, pubofemoral, and ischiofemoral ligaments, tightening the joint capsule overall.
applied_example: This position is used to assess end-range stability in orthopedic exams.
text: Which movement stretches all three capsular ligaments of the hip simultaneously?

question: The ischiofemoral ligament reinforces which part of the hip joint?
short_explanation: It reinforces the posterior aspect of the hip joint.
long_explanation: The ischiofemoral ligament arises from the ischium and spirals to attach to the femoral neck posteriorly, helping limit internal rotation and extension.
applied_example: Posterior hip pain during rotation may involve this ligament.
text: The ischiofemoral ligament reinforces which part of the hip joint?

question: Which ligament is least involved in hip joint stabilization but plays a key role in vascular supply during childhood?
short_explanation: Ligamentum teres has a vascular role in youth.
long_explanation: While structurally weak in adults, the ligamentum teres is vital for delivering blood to the femoral head during development.
applied_example: Avascular necrosis in children may relate to trauma of this ligament.
text: Which ligament is least involved in hip joint stabilization but plays a key role in vascular supply during childhood?

question: Which ligament primarily resists excessive abduction and external rotation of the hip?
short_explanation: The pubofemoral ligament controls abduction and external rotation.
long_explanation: Originating from the pubic portion of the pelvis and blending with the joint capsule, the pubofemoral ligament limits excessive abduction and external rotation to maintain joint stability.
applied_example: Injury here could lead to instability in lateral leg movements.
text: Which ligament primarily resists excessive abduction and external rotation of the hip?
